document.text: York Has Mystery Which Put Eleven Negroes In Danger.. York, Pa.The bouse of G. W. Wood, on King and Patterson streets, this city, was blown up by dynamite shortly after midnight this morning. Eleven negroes occupied the house at the time of the explosion and that they were not all killed seems a mys tery. It is alleged that a man threat ened to blow tbe bouse to pieces o Christmas night if his wife did not rt. turn to him.

document.text: With emphasis on symphony or chestras, Jessie Patterson, professor of music at Longwood College, spoke on music appreciation at a meeting of the Womans Club of Appomattox Monday afternoon. The meeting was held at Liberty Baptist Church. During a brief business session, the club named Mrs. Martin L. Webb as a delegate to the Alice Kyle Dis trict meeting. This meeting will be held in Kenbridge on March 10. Mrs. Richard D. Robinson was named as alternate delegate. Mrs. Harold Y. Spencer announc ed that the March meeting will be sponsored by the American Home and Conservation Department. This will be a dinner meeting and will be held at the local school cafeteria. Mrs. Frank F. Carr is chairman of this department.

document.text: whs to those good people who had purchased their spring bonnets and nw suits for display oa Easter! But this weather will not last al ways, and the bonnets and new suits will keep. Notwithstanding the Bevere cold and frequent frosts, wheat and oats are looking very well and all the peaches are not killed. Mr. W. H. Walden has com pleted his commodious store house and is now doing business again Ho carries a good stock of first class goods. Mr. Hunter Brightwell will be gin building next week. Dr. J. F. Alsop will also erect an office on part of the Walden lot, and then our town will be more attractive than ever. Effort is being made to put a new fence around the new passenger yard. W. H. Walden has just com pleted a splendid new paling fence around his residence property. The ladies are making an effort to pnt reflectors in onr church. They believe in plenty of light. Last Thursday Master Bernard Carter had the misfortune to break the small bone in one of his wrists. In running he stumbled and fell, catching his weight upon one hand. wih the above result. On Sunday, the lOib, Mr. E S. Taylor suffered a sudden and se vere attack of illueis. He is now up again, but shows the effect oi his Buffering. Our telephone line is about com pletcd and several of the instru ments have been put np. We art . beginning to feel that we are the people. Capt. W. E. OConnor, accompa nied by his wife, daughter and Master Alfred Tweedy, attended the launching of the battleship Vir ginia at Newport News. Our public schools are closed. Mr. Hunter Brightwell left Sunday for Eastern Shore. On Wednesday, the 13tb, there was a qniet wedding at the parson age. The contracting parties were Mr. Cowan Patterson and Miss Lelia M. Dunam, both of Appo mattox county. Only the pastorr family and a brother of the bride witnessed the ceremony. Oharles A. Oliver, sixteen years of age, after a long and painfnl ill ness, died at his home near I pact on the 13th instant. He was  buried in Prospect Cemetery, Rev. P. M. Bel, his pastor, conducting  the services. He was of a quiet, gentle disposition and seemed to I shrink from the bustle and noise of the crowd, but in his long sick ness he was patient and oalm. The bereaved family have the sympathy of the whole community.

document.text: were issued to Max Willard, New York, through Patterson, Reed  Patterson, attorneys, Washington, D. C., for a new explosive called willardite, reputed to be the most powerful in existence. For several months secret negotiation have been in progress between Wil lard and the U. S. government. While Tom had a feeling that this information, if, properly understood, would clear up much that was secret and obscure respecting Willard and his conduct, still it did not enlighten him in any way. Indeed, it was all the more baffling that the Intelligence should come voluntarily from the Man of Iron. He puzzled fruitlessly over it a while, then asked Whats this got to do with either the murder or Miss Carew? Nothing, cheerfully returned the detective, folding the slip of paper and depositing it in his wallet, nothing whatever. Goqd day! And he left Tom more perplexed and mystified than ever.

document.text: we keen and the uncertainty of our schedules makes meal planning and taking part in social activities quite a chore. gg  Moon, living in the Spout Sp mg area as a mild, attended grade school at Spout Spring sad came to the Appomattox County public school system in the seventh grade. He graduated from  Appomattox High School hi 1940. At the beginning of World War H, Moon went to   Juliens Creek Ammunition Depot for the Norfolk Navy Yard. In the fitil of 1948 he tfhinteered for service in the U. S. Maritime Service. Following basic training in New York, I went front New York Across country by train to San Francisco and my first voyage out of the country was to New Guinea on a troop ship. I was working in the engine room, commented Moon. Moons travels with the Maritime Service took him to many countries. The war ended in Europe while I was in Russia, said Moon. I came home and Gladys and I were married in 1945. I made one trip, came home and attended Officers School at New London, Connecticut and got my commission. Next I took the Coast Guard examination and attended Diesel School at Sheeps Head Bay. Moon was discharged in August of 1946 and entered VPI to begin his studies in pre-pharmacy. He entered the Medical College School of Pharmacy in 1947 completing his work in 1950. As pharmacist. Moon went to Grays Drug Store in Farmville, then to Rivermont Avenue Phar macy, Patterson Drug Store on Main Street and on Norfolk Avenue

document.text: We insert in this issue the follow ing excerpts from two of our ex changes as illustrative of the distin guished ability and the wide-spread popularity of our fellow citizen, Hon. D. Flood, and as indicative of how entirely he deserves our highest es teem. Notwithstanding the inclement weather a large crowd attended Buckingham court Sept. 18. Hon. H. D. Flood was advertised to address the Democracy, and he proved to be a drawing card. At 12 oclock the meeting was called to order, and Hon. Camm Patterson, the Democratic nominee for the Legislature, led off in a short, timely, impressive speech devoted to the arraignment of the Third party, showing the fallacies of the platform, and the foolishness of their demands. He was listened to throughout with marked attention and was enthusiastically applauded from start to the finish. Mr. H. D. Flood followed Captain Patterson, and delighted his audience with finished oratory and overwhelm ing arguments. He reviewed the his tory of the Democratic party, and at tributed the conception and establish ment of onr most cherished institu tions to its broad patriotism and statesmanship. His speech was bold and aggressive, and he had the effect of warming up and setting to work many who were indifferent. Several other distinguished gentlemen made short speeches, after which the meet ing adjonrned, enthused and in g eat good humor. Prior to the meeting of the Demo cracy, the Populists met in conven tion, and nominated L. C. Moseley as their candidate for the Legislature. Mr. Moseley has hitherto been a Democrat, and as such has held the office of Sheriff, and served also in. the Legislature. Personally he is a man of influence, and will develop some strength. Hon. E. R. Cocke made his appear ance here before the Convention, and was warmly greeted by those of his faith. He declined a joint debate with Messrs. Patterson and Flood on any terms, and addressed his own crowd. It is at once perceptible that Captain Cocke is not a trained public speaker. His effort was laborious and studied and not calculated to arouse enthusiasm, yet he leaves the impression of being a well informed and scholarly gentleman. His bear ing was dignified and courteous, and upon the whole he made a fair im pression upon his hearers. His vote in this county will not be large, for the Democracy is spendidly organiz ed, alert and vigilant.Richmond Times.

document.text: WASHINGTON.Borrowing from British experience, the war depart ment announced that thè policy of farming Out arms contracts to small firms would be applied vigors ously in this country to distribute the defense load as Widely as pos sible. . Holders of defense contracts will be encouraged, the announcement said, to sublet substantial parts of the work, and each will be expect ed to select his own sub-contractors. Announcing thé appointment of Joseph L. and Francis Trecker of Milwaukee as special advisers on farming out methods, Robert F. Patterson, undersecretary of war, said the ptolicy would be employed more and more as the burden on larger firms increases. Bits and Pieces Policy. The British government first turned to the farming out princi ple, known in England as the bits and pieces policy, late iij the sum mer of 1938 when the aircraft in dustry there was asked to sublet a minimum of 35 per cent of its work on government orders. The announcement said Germany also has been applying the formula with even mòre intensive thorough- ness. . .. Yis explanation was given of the

document.text: Washington Special.The Sen ate Wednesday accepted the propo sition of the House of Representa tives to increase the salaries of sena tors, members and territorial dele gates to 7,500 annually, and those of the Vice President, the Speaker of the House and members of the Presidents Cabinet to 12,000. This action was taken by a vote of 53 to 21, and followed a discussion of nearly three hours. An amendment confining the increase to Cabinet of ficers and the presiding officers of the Senate and House was voted down, as was also a proposition to postpone the increase until 1913. The increase becomes effective March 4, 1909. The House provision was carried by, a vote of 53 to 21, the details of the vote being as follows Yeas  Aldrich, Allee, Ankeny, Benson, Beveridge, Brandegee, Balk- ley, Burnham, Burrows, Carter,Clark Mqnt., Clark Wyo., Clarke Ark., Crane, Cullom, Daniel, Dick, Dillingham, Dubois, Du Pont, Flinty Foraker, Foster, Frye, Fulton, Gal- lii.ger, Hale, Heyburn, Hopkins, Kit- tredge, Knox, Latimer, Lodge, Long, McCumber, McEnery, Millard, Money, Newlands, Nixon, Overman, Penrose, Pettus, Piles, Scott, Simmons, Smoot, Spooner, Sutherland, Teller, Tillman, Warner and Warren53. Nays  Bacon, Berry, Blackburn, Burkett, Carmack, Clapp, Clay, Cul berson, Frazier, Hansbrough, Hemen- way, Lafollette, McCreary, Mallory, Nelson, Patterson, Perkins, Rayner, Stone, Taliaferro and Whyte21. A conference committee was ap pointed as to the other matters of disagreement between the House and Senate on the Legislative Bill. In the debate which proceeded the adoption of the salary increase pro position, Mr. Berry contended that 5,000 was not a grossly inadequate salary for senators and members of Congress. He denied that they could not live on that amount. There is not one-half of them, he declared, who ever could or did make 5,000 a year engaged in any other busi ness. Senator Nelson offered an amend ment confining the increase to the vice president, speaker and cabinet officers, and spoke in support of it. He said We as legislators are paid higher than legislators of any oilier .country. Mr. Nelson then gave fig ures showing the salaries paid to legislators in European countries, and, continuing his argument, spoke with resentment of the idea that legislators were here as laborers for a salary. Theirs was a post of honor, and pay enough to live mod estly was sufficient. We do not want to enter the social world, he asserted. He then expressed satis faction that some senators and mem bers have ambition in that line, and have the means to mingle socially with diplomats, etc. Mr. Gallinger supported the pro posed Increase. He said be believed public opinion was in favor of the increase. We have been increasing salaries all along the line except our own. Each member must make political contributions. This was just, he said, and so were many oth er demands which could not be evad ed. He said the entire extra expense to the government would be only about 1,000,000 annually. Mr. Lodge, in favoring the in crease, said that members of the English Parliament received no sal aries that the Irish members, who were poor, received contributions from the people of their districts and from this country that the labor members were paid by their labor unions. This, he asserted, was a bad system, and he believed Great Britain was coming to recognize -ft. AN INDIAN SLAYER. I

document.text: Walking in the right path. One per son joined the church at the end of the message. Miss Nellie Williams and Miss Braxton spent the week-end at their homes. Rev. R. Q. Lawing and Mrs. T. M Harris attended a special planning meeting of the V. T. A. in Richmond last Saturday. Deacon Charlie Patterson of the Morning Star church is undergoing special treatment at the Lynchburg General Hospital. All patrons and friends are ask ed to attend the regular meeting of the Carver-Price P.-T. A. on Mon day evening at 730. Special reports will be made concerning the pro gram of work. This is the first meet ing for 1955 and all members are asked to be present and on time. Acting principal J. A. Clay spent the week-end at his home in Rich mond, Va. Also the following teach ers spent the week-end at home Mrs. Hale and Professor Miller. The James River Four Quartet, of Lynchburg will sing at the Jor dan Baptist Church Sunday night, January 23, at 730 P. M. Also there will be a weight rally at the same time, sponsored by the choir. There will be a special church meeting at the Jordan Baptist Church on January 22 at 200 P. M. All members please be present.

document.text: W ell W ater Notes. A very sad of case drowning occurd at Mauteo Station on the C.  O. R. R. on Friday the 12th, instant. Jesse Moseley a highly respected colored man, who carries the mail from Man- teo P. O. in Buckingham county across the river to the Station, with two section hands undertook to cross the river in a skiff. The river was very high, the current too strong for them. They were carried against the wire rope of the ferry which caught theboat and upset it, and the three men were thrown in the river.. Mosley managed to catch hold of the wire rope and held on to it for over I anhonr, when he let go fromexhaus-1 tion and being unable to swim he was drowned. The other two men swam I , to Sycamore Island aud climed a tree j where they had to stay until a mes-1 senger could go to Wingina for a boat and help, when they were res cued from their fearful situation almost frozen. While Jesse Mosley was holding to the rope Mr. Geo, W. Patterson, a Merchant at Manteo, offered 100 to any one who would rescue him, several attemps were made but each one failed thie cur rent being too strond. j During the great freshet of 18701 Jesse Mosley rescued a young lady I a Mrs wright, from the same tree the two men climed. She was in a house I that floated down until it struck the island and dashed to pieces, when the young lady escaped nrowhing by climbing this tree. Mrs John R. Agee whose illness I reported several weeks ago died on Sunday night the 6th, iinstant and was hurried Tuesday at the family I burying ground. She was about 70 years old, a consistant member of the j  Baptist Church, and highly esteemed bv all who knew her. Her husband and four sous survive her, and to them we extend our deepest sympa thy in this sorce berevemeut. Mr. J. Jas Ranson has been quite sick again for the last two weeks, and is still confined to his room, it is very doubtful if he can leave the house before the spring. The T imes has many admiers in this locality, and is read with much  interest. The Contract for tbe new Masonic hall at centenary wil1 be let at the next regular meeting of Taylor Lodge Feb 20th, 1865. Jan. 19th, 1895.

document.text: W arm inster. The sad death of Mr. T. W. Cash I took place at his home at Midway I Mills, Va., on Sunday at 2 oclock a. m. Feb. 19th. The burial ser vices were conducted by Dr. T. H.I Lacy, of Blacksburg. Acting pall -1 bearers were his six nephews John I W., W. L .E . M., J. B. and W. E. Gash, all of Bluefield, and D. Henry Taylor, of Lexington. Among others present were J. J. Patterson, of Augusta J. B. Taylor, of East Lexington, Geo. Mathews and daughter, Miss Maggie, of Lynch burg and onr o-d friend, Mr. John Gash, brother of the deceased. He leaves to monrn their loss a wife, who was a Miss Garrett, of Buck ingham two daughters, Mrs. I. M. Spears, of -Manteo, and Miss Nettie I Gash, of Midway Mills one eon, Mr. I Houston Cash atid two brothers, I John and James Gash. Quite a large crowd attended the bnrial and the floral designs were beautiful. It was one of the most impressive burials I ever attended and the grief of the mauy loved ones was very pathetic. He was known and loved by every one that had the pleasure to cross his path. They have onr deepest sympathy.

Mrs.Paradise has returned home from a visit to New York, Rev. A . E .Jordon was called to Crozet last Thursday to preach the funeral of one of his church deac ons.

document.text: VIRGINIA IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF APPOMATTOX COUNTY. VINCENT PATTERSON, et als, Plaintiffs, vs. COLLIER T. PATTERSON, et als, Defendants. SHOW CAUSE ORDER This m atter came on to be heard upon the Motion of Vin cent Patterson and Almeter P. Finley, of counsel, to substitute Helen Patterson, Administra trix of the Estate of Collier T. Patterson, deceased, and the in fant children of Collier T. Patt erson, as parties Defendant in the above styled suit now pend ing in the Circuit Court of this county. And the Court being of the opinion that Collier T. P atter son was the named Defendant in the above styled action, and who died on March 1,1972, survived by his widow, Helen Patterson, and two infant children, Vanessa Patterson and Collier T. Patt erson, Jr., both infants that Helen Patterson has qualified as Administratrix of the Estate of Collier T. Patterson, deceased, and that accordingly, the Court does ORDER and DECREE that Helen Patterson, Administra trix of the Estate of Collier T Patterson, deceased, and Va nessa Patterson and Collier T. Patterson, both infants, do show cause, if any they can, on the 10th day of June, 1972, at 900 A.M., before this Court,why the above captioned suit now pend ing in this Court shall not pro ceed in their names as Substi tuted parties of Collier T. Pat terson, deceased. It is further ORDERED that a copy of this Order be published in the Times-Virginian, a news paper of general circulation in Appomattox County, Virginia for four consecutive weeks. ENTER Judge George F. Abbitt, Jr Date 4-28-72 A Copy - Teste Aldah B. Gordon, Clerk I ask for this Robert W. C arter Attorney for Plantiffs. 5-4-4t

ORDER OF PUBLICATION The object of this suit is to effect partition in one of the modes prescribed by law of cer tain parcels of real estate, be longing, lying and being in Clov- erhill Magisterial District and Southside Magisterial District of Appomattox County, Virginia, of which Hattie W. Patterson died, testate, seized and pos sessed thereof, being a3.0acre parcel in Cloverhfll District, adjoined by Norfolk  Western Railway, conveyed to Charles Patterson by Henrietta Wom ack, et als, by Deed dated 21 October, 1907, of record in the Clerks Office of this Court in Deed Book 10 at page 38 a 40-18 acre parcel and a 119.7 acre parcel, being contiguous tracts conveyed to Charlie Pat terson by two separate Deeds, the first dated 24 April, 1937,of record in the aforesaid Clerks Office in Deed Book 36 at page 324, and the second, dated 30 May, 1944, of record in the aforesaid Clerks Office in Deed Book 43 at page 25, lying in Cloverhill Magisterial District of Appomattox County, lying on both sides of the county road leading from Appomattox to Evergreen, LESS, HOWEVER, two off-conveyances being 5.0 acres each, devised under the last will and testament of Char les E. Patterson to Almeter P. Finley and Audrey Patterson, and a 1.0 acre parcel conveyed by Hattie W. Patterson, widow of Charles E. Patterson, to Wil liam P. Baker, et ux, by Deed dated 15 February, 1966, of re cord in the aforesaid Clerks Office in Deed Book 85 at page 566 and a 40 12 acre parcel, more or less. In Southside Mag- sterial District of Appomattox County, Virginia, situated on the Northeast side of Patrick Ann Lane in the Town of Appomat tox, being adjoined by the lands now or formerly owned by Lee Patterson, Estate ofH. D. FloocL and Adelia C. Ferguson, Lucy A. Cumby, Earl Patterson, Oc- tavia Caldwell, Jubber T. Mc- D a ni e l, et als, conveyed to Charlie E. Patterson by Deed dated 11 December, 1947, of re cord in the aforesaid Clerks Office in Deed Book 49 at page 205, and being the same pro perty of which Hattie W. Patt erson died, testate, seized and possessed thereof. An affidavit having been made and filed that Collier T. Patter son, Hubert J. Patterson, Gla dys T. Cheatham, Arnold Pat terson, Monroe P a t t e r s o n , Doris P. Wright, Olga P. Pratt, and Audrey Patterson, Defend ants, are not residents of the State of Virginia It is ORDERED that the non resident Defendants do appear within ten days afer due publication onis order and do what may be necessary to pro tect their Interests in this suit. Teste

document.text: VIRGINIA 4-HERS TO COMPETE AT ATLANTIC RURAL EXPOSITION Virginia 4-Hers will again flock to the fairmany of them to com pete for sizeable awards at the At lantic Rural Exposition in Rich mond, September 24 to October 2. On Monday, September 27, live stock, dairy, and poultry judging teams from Virginia and eight oth er states ill compete. Virginias dairy judging team is composed of Gilbert Birdall and Bernard Blake, both of Gloucester Sidney Spahr, Patrick and Bobby Albrite, Rocking ham. The state livestock judging team is composed of Clares Flora and Max Brough, both of Botetourt James Grove, Augusta and Wayne Hodge, Norfolk. Members of the poultry judging team are Wayne Wetzel and Charles Lichliter, both of Shenandoah C. J. Martin, Franklin and Kenneth Washburn, Hgnry. J. M. Tyree, associate state 4-H agent, VPI, will be in charge of the 4-H judging contests, with H. E Henderson, W. N. Patterson, and Denver Bragg acting as general su perintendents of the livestock, dairy and poultry events, respectively. Each judging contest carries as premiums 50 down for top teams 15 down for top individuals. On Tuesday, September 28, John Etzler, a Botetourt 4-Heh, will compete in the tractor operator contest against drivers from 12 At lantic coast states. The entries come from Rhode Island to Florida. Cash awards range from 25 down. W. W Turner, associate state 4-H agent at VPI, will be in charge. Four-T officials say a record num ber of 4-H exhibits are expected this year.
